channel.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 Cable News Network LP, LLLP.

image.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
image.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.

item.title: France confirms al Qaeda militant killed
item.description: France confirmed for the first time Saturday that Islamist militant Abdelhamid Abou Zeid was killed amid fighting by French forces in northern Mali late last month.

item.title: Thai refugee camp blaze kills dozens
item.description: Authorities investigate after a fire at a camp in northern Thailand kills more than 30 refugees from Myanmar, and destroys hundreds of huts -- leaving 2,300 homeless.

item.title: Taliban threaten to kill Musharraf
item.description: The Pakistani Taliban will assassinate former President Pervez Musharraf if he returns to the country as planned on Sunday, a spokesman for the terrorist group said Saturday in a video message online.

item.title: Chinese president visits Moscow
item.description: CNN's David McKenzie reports on Xi Jinping's first overseas trip as Chinese president to Moscow.

item.title: Xi Jinping's first state visit to old foe
item.description: China's President Xi Jinping's choice of Moscow as his first foreign capital visit is being seen by analysts as a symbolic move that demonstrates the increasing interdependence of the one-time Cold War foes.

item.title: Reported meteor lights up U.S. coast
item.description: The streaking ball of fire Friday night above the East Coast did not, for now at least, signal the end to civilization as we know it.

item.title: Buddhists, Muslims clash in Myanmar
item.description: Buddhist monks and others armed with swords and machetes stalk the streets of a city in central Myanmar where sectarian violence has left about 20 people dead, local officials say.

item.title: Deadly tornado strikes Bangladesh
item.description: At least 20 people were killed and more than 200 injured when a powerful tornado ripped through the southeastern district of Brahmanbaria in Bangladesh late Friday afternoon, officials said.

item.title: Fake pilot gets into airliner cockpit
item.description: The angry Frenchman came upon an audacious solution when he couldn't fly business class, a plan worthy of "Catch Me If You Can."

item.title: Child at airport 'crushed' by falling sign
item.description: A display board at an Alabama airport crashed down Friday, killing a child and injuring at least one other person, hospital and airport officials said.

item.title: Driver tries to outrun tornado
item.description: CNN's Erin Burnett reports on dramatic video of a tornado in Australia.

item.title: UK put on negative watch by Fitch
item.description: Fitch has warned it could strip the UK of its triple A rating next month, just days after George Osborne, the chancellor, admitted the recovery would be slower and borrowing higher than had been thought.

item.title: Youths arrested after baby shot in face
item.description: Two teenagers were arrested Friday in the shooting death of a 13-month-old boy who was in his stroller, according to police in this coastal city.

item.title: FBI looks for links in U.S. shootings
item.description: Days after he led police in a wild car chase that ended in a hail of gunfire, authorities are investigating the driver's links to two Colorado killings. And whether he has ties to a third shooting, in Texas, earlier this year.

item.title: Azarenka's boyfriend sings to inspire
item.description: Her popstar boyfriend has written a song about her "heart of a champion," but Victoria Azarenka is struggling to get on court at the moment.

item.title: Football: Draw dents Spain's 2014 hopes
item.description: Finland ruined Sergio Ramos' 100th appearance for Spain on Friday as the planet's 87th-ranked team held the No. 1 side and defending World Cup champion in a qualifier for next year's tournament in Brazil.

item.title: Golf: Tiger vows to 'clean up'
item.description: If Tiger Woods fails in his double bid to retain the Bay Hill title and regain his world No. 1 ranking this weekend, then it's a fair bet he'll be ruing his late lapses on the opening two days.

item.title: F1: Ice-cool Raikkonen on top in Malaysia
item.description: Kimi Raikkonen is not a driver to get unduly excited.

item.title: How Obama has weaponized wit
item.description: Barack Obama would make a great stand-up comic, not because he's the funniest president ever but because he uses jokes the same way many of us comedians do: as a weapon.

item.title: Gillard wins battle, but war in doubt
item.description: They may go down in Australian political history as misguided heroes.

item.title: No one should be fired for being gay
item.description: He didn't want them to know his secret.

item.title: How will Turkey respond to PKK move?
item.description: It was Newrouz, the first day of spring and the Kurdish New Year but was it also the beginning of a new era in Turkey's troubled relation with its Kurdish population?

item.title: Opinion: EU bailouts kicking the weak?
item.description: The recent financial troubles in Cyprus have attracted a range of alarming headlines around the world, but we must be careful to avoid panic and reckless measures that would exacerbate the crisis.

item.title: Hope for Pakistan and Afghanistan
item.description: Peter Bergen says Pakistan is more stable than many think, and there are reasons for hope in Afghanistan

item.title: Girl cruelty plays role in rape culture
item.description: In order to prevent future incidents like the rape of a teenager in Steubenville, Ohio, girls need to be taught to be allies, not rivals, Rachel Simmons says.

item.title: A lunch of two popes: Francis and Benedict break bread
item.description: The newly installed Pope Francis lunches with his predecessor, Pope Emeritus Benedict XVI, in what may be an encounter unprecedented in the history of the Catholic Church.

item.title: The pope in retirement: What to expect
item.description: Don't expect a lot of shuffleboard games for the soon-to-be former Bishop of Rome, Successor of St. Peter, Head of the College of Bishops, Vicar of Christ, and Pastor of the Universal Church: Pope Benedict XVI.

item.title: Will Pope Francis be a reformer?
item.description: Father Edward Beck, Richard Socarides & Cameron Russell on if Pope Francis can change church's stance on gay marriage.

item.title: Cyprus for Easter? Pack extra cash
item.description: The financial uncertainty in Cyprus is generating images of long lines at ATM machines and anti-European Union protests.

item.title: Bank clerks worry they'll lose home
item.description: The Cyprus debt crisis is being felt by the banks but also by the people who work at them. Nick Paton Walsh reports.

item.title: Why Russia is so worried
item.description: CNN'sPhil Black talks to Russia's former finance minister about how Moscow should respond to the Cyprus financial crisis.

item.title: Explainer: What happened in Cyprus?
item.description: Cyprus has become the latest eurozone nation to apply for a bailout amid a financial crisis linked to debt defaults in Greece. The Mediterranean island has a huge banking sector and its public debt is expected to match GDP within the next decade. Proposals to tax existing bank deposits as part of a rescue package have alarmed investors. The Cypriot parliament on March 19 rejected a â‚¬10 billion ($13B) eurozone bailout package due to investor alarm over a proposed tax on existing bank deposits as part of the rescue package.

item.title: Obama scores diplomatic success
item.description: Barack Obama ends his trip to the Middle East in Jordan, but not before scoring a diplomatic coup with Israel's apology to Turkey for its 2010 attack on a Gaza flotilla.

item.title: Israel apologizes for deadly flotilla raid
item.description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologizes to Turkey for the 2010 raid on the Gaza-bound flotilla that killed nine activists.

item.title: Obama's reputation in Israel
item.description: John King talks about the reaction the president received from the Israeli public during his first trip there in office.

item.title: Tracking huge great white shark
item.description: Here's a view from aboard a fishing boat of what it's like to nab and tag a great white shark for research purposes.

item.title: Becker: Ronaldo the tennis ace?
item.description: Cristiano Ronaldo has the perfect physique for tennis, according to tennis great Boris Becker.

item.title: 'Miniature TV' in your tummy
item.description: PillCam is a ingestible video camera with a transmitter which lets doctors look inside your digestive tract.

item.title: The man behind 'Lara Croft'
item.description: Ian Livingstone is a legend in the fantasy games world. In 1995, he stumbled upon "Lara Croft" and the rest is history.

item.title: Rodman: Kim Jong Un 'my friend'
item.description: Ato Boldon, Politico's Ben Smith and Reihan Salam discuss criticism over Dennis Rodman's trip to North Korea.

item.title: Marcel Desailly's Ghana regret
item.description: French World Cup winning defender Marcel Desailly tells CNN that he would have loved to play for Ghana at least once.

item.title: 'Batman' helps UK police
item.description: A costumed crusader brought in a man wanted for burglary.

item.title: Go inside a sinkhole
item.description: Ever wonder what a sinkhole looks like on the inside? CNN's David Mattingly dives in for a peek in Florida.

item.title: David to Ziggy and back
item.description: A new exhibition features hundreds of objects from Bowie's life, from stage outfits to rare photos.

item.title: Behind the scenes
item.description: Take a look behind the scenes of "David Bowie Is" -- a new exhibition at London's Victoria and Albert Museum.

item.title: History of Bowie in 15 objects
item.description: A history of David Bowie in 15 objects

item.title: What's behind Syria's chemical threat?
item.description: The specter of chemical weapons has been hanging over war-torn Syria for months. Experts believe the regime may have sarin, nerve agents and mustard gas. CNN assesses the threat.

item.title: Will Cypriot tourism survive turmoil?
item.description: With financial uncertainty generating images of long lines at cash machines and anti-European Union protests in Cyprus, travel experts offer their advice on the island's tourist trade.

item.title: Syrians came, 'now we wait for bread'
item.description: In one dusty Jordanian neighborhood that locals call Syria Town, children peer from shops that once sold sweets. As 450,000 refugees flood a region of high unemployment, wealthy Syrian expats are trying to ease tensions.

item.title: Why author Achebe will be so missed
item.description: The death of Chinua Achebe represents more than the loss of a great writer. Achebe was perhaps the first to give voice with elegance, a poetic prose, and startling insight to the other side of the world which most Western readers encounter in Joseph Conrad.

item.title: A history of David Bowie in 15 objects
item.description: Blockbuster exhibition follows highs and lows, from synths to saxophones, catsuits to cocaine spoons.

item.title: Jagger can teach you about parenting
item.description: Ruben Navarrette says being a good parent is about teaching adult children to stand on their own two feet.

item.title: How saucy texts came 'close to crime'
item.description: The European Parliament recently voted on a bill titled "Eliminating Gender Stereotypes in the EU." A laudable goal, for sure -- but activists characterized the bill as a Trojan horse with chilling effects on free speech and opinion. The response from the European Parliament left much to be desired in terms of respect for democracy and voters.

item.title: Couple loses 500 pounds in two years
item.description: Angela and Willie Gillis credit their relationship for helping them eat right, exercise more and adopt a healthy lifestyle.

item.title: Ice-cool Raikkonen on top in Malaysia
item.description: Kimi Raikkonen is not a driver to get unduly excited.

item.title: How serious are Pyongyang's threats?
item.description: Video propaganda showing the White House blown up. Talk of hitting U.S. bases. The renunciation of a 60-year-old armistice that has peace on the Korean Peninsula. What is North Korea's young leader doing?

item.title: Does Kenya condom ad promote adultery?
item.description: CNN's Nima Elbagir reports on an AIDS ad in Kenya promoting condom use and the scrutiny that has come with it.

item.title: Lawyer fights Malawi 'widow sex' tradition
item.description: Lawyer and human rights activist Seodi White has long been an outspoken campaigner for gender justice in Malawi, a country where half its women are married before the age of 18.

item.title: Why oceans face collapse
item.description: As the human footprint has spread, our remaining wilderness areas have retreated. CNN charts the health of the world's oceans.

item.title: Donated art revealed as $30M portrait
item.description: A mystery portrait donated to a British heritage charity as part of a mixed lot of paintings has been identified as a work by Dutch master Rembrandt van Rijn -- worth more than $30 million.

item.title: Ex-dancer: Bolshoi acts like brothel
item.description: Former Bolshoi prima ballerina Anastasia Volochkova talks to CNN about her experience at the ballet and the controversy.

item.title: Where do super rich live?
item.description: Growing ranks of super rich have doubled global real estate values the past seven years, a new report says.

item.title: Africa's 'tallest building' planned
item.description: Right now, it's nothing more than an empty plot of land, covered by just a few shrubs and the odd Neem tree. But within a few years, these grass plains just outside Accra, Ghana, could be transformed into a fertile breeding ground for world-class innovation.

item.title: Syrians came, 'now we wait for bread'
item.description: There are so many refugees living in one neighborhood here that locals have started calling it Syria Town.

item.title: Is this candidate in Mexico an escort?
item.description: A candidate for political office in Mexico is accused of working as an escort in Las Vegas. CNN's Rafael Romo reports.

item.title: Disney: Magical -- or manipulative?
item.description: There's no shortage of passion on the topic of Disney. It's pure magic for many travelers. But for others the princesses and the commercialism put Disney's empire firmly on their must-not-see lists.

item.title: The worst city for light pollution?
item.description: If you want a place to see the majestic sweep of the Milky Way -- or even any star at night -- then put Hong Kong at the bottom of your must-visit list.

item.title: Why author Achebe will be so missed
item.description: The death of Chinua Achebe represents more than the loss of a great writer. Achebe was perhaps the first to give voice with elegance, a poetic prose, and startling insight to the other side of the world which most Western readers encounter in Joseph Conrad.

item.title: Saucy texts came 'close to crime'
item.description: The European Parliament recently voted on a bill titled "Eliminating Gender Stereotypes in the EU." A laudable goal, for sure -- but activists characterized the bill as a Trojan horse with chilling effects on free speech and opinion. The response from the European Parliament left much to be desired in terms of respect for democracy and voters.

item.title: Cattle-class to horse-class
item.description: Ever felt like cattle on an economy flight? If the four-legged racing celebrities being flown around the world in luxury are any indication, you might want an upgrade to "horse-class."

item.title: Should Beckham have gone to PSG?
item.description: Catch all the CNN FC off-field talk, as Pedro Pinto, Ian Wright and others discuss Becks' career as well as racism in football.

item.title: Living Golf meets Bubba Watson
item.description: A sneak preview of Living Golf's shoot with defending Masters champion Bubba Watson.

item.title: Is end to global thirst in sight?
item.description: When one looks back at humanity's great achievements, what do we think of -- the moon landings, decoding the human genome, elimination of small-pox, the invention of penicillin -- all have left their mark on our collective history.

item.title: Bartender turns wine to water
item.description: Doc Hendley's nonprofit, Wine to Water, has helped provide clean water to more than 150,000 people in 15 countries.

item.title: Are land grabs really water grabs?
item.description: Investors buying African land for farming can create water shortages for local farmers and communities, argue experts.

item.title: Germans adopt Syrian rebels
item.description: CNN's Fred Pleitgen reports on a German aid group that lets donors "adopt" Syrian revolutionary organizations.

item.title: Big Bang snap tells us about evolution
item.description: The picture of the early universe just got much sharper, and tells scientists with precision many important facts about how the universe evolved.

item.title: Why oceans face catastrophic collapse
item.description: As the human footprint has spread, our remaining wilderness areas have retreated. CNN charts the health of the world's oceans.

item.title: Probing undiscovered depths
item.description: Despite most humans' land-centric view, Earth is an ocean planet. The global ocean covers more than two-thirds of our planet's surface and makes life as we know it possible: it produces half of the oxygen we breathe, helps regulate our climate and provides the single largest habitat for life on Earth.

item.title: Iraq War was 'terrible mistake'
item.description: Hans Blix was the head of U.N. weapons inspections in the build up to the 2003 invasion. He says the war violated the U.N. charter, replacing tyranny with anarchy.

item.title: Hans Blix tells CNN Iraq war illegal
item.description: Hans Blix, former U.N. chief weapons inspector, talks to CNN on the 10-year anniversary of the Iraq war.

item.title: Iraq 'better off' without Hussein
item.description: Former U.S. Administrator in Iraq Paul Bremer talks to CNN on the 10-year anniversary of the Iraq war.

item.title: Could there be a strike on Iran?
item.description: With pundits predicting military action in "spring or summer", basic questions need answers, says CNN's Jim Clancy.

item.title: Obama: 'All options on the table'
item.description: Israel's Channel 2 News sat down with U.S. President Obama and talked about his position on Iran's nuclear program.

item.title: Could there be a strike on Iran?
item.description: Plenty of pundits are laying out a "spring or summer" timeline for military action, says CNN's Jim Clancy. But decision-makers must answer some basic questions about the nuclear threat from Iran.

item.title: Soccer star calls for action in racism battle
item.description: Kevin-Prince Boateng tells CNN he wants referees to have "all the power" in the game's bid to stamp out racism on and off the pitch.

item.title: Boateng: Racism must end
item.description: CNN's Amanda Davies has an exclusive interview with AC Milan's Kevin-Prince Boateng on racism in football.

item.title: Obama's wit
item.description: Barack Obama would make a great stand-up comic, not because he's the funniest president ever but because he uses jokes the same way many of us comedians do: as a weapon.

item.title: Iran strategy
item.description: Plenty of pundits are laying out a "spring or summer" timeline for military action, says CNN's Jim Clancy. But decision-makers must answer some basic questions about the nuclear threat from Iran.

item.title: Soccer racism
item.description: CNN's Amanda Davies has an exclusive interview with AC Milan's Kevin-Prince Boateng on racism in football.

item.title: Bolshoi ballet
item.description: Former Bolshoi prima ballerina Anastasia Volochkova talks to CNN about her experience at the ballet and the controversy.

item.title: U.S. meteor?
item.description: The streaking ball of fire Friday night above the East Coast did not, for now at least, signal the end to civilization as we know it.

item.title: Flying horses
item.description: Once you've battled through the queues, check-in, extortionate on board snacks and cramped seating, it's no wonder so many economy airline passengers complain about flying "cattle-class."

item.title: David Bowie
item.description: Blockbuster exhibition follows highs and lows, from synths to saxophones, catsuits to cocaine spoons.

item.title: Oceans threat
item.description: As the human footprint has spread, our remaining wilderness areas have retreated. CNN charts the health of the world's oceans.

item.title: Robots probe ocean depths
item.description: Despite most humans' land-centric view, Earth is an ocean planet. The global ocean covers more than two-thirds of our planet's surface and makes life as we know it possible: it produces half of the oxygen we breathe, helps regulate our climate and provides the single largest habitat for life on Earth.

item.title: Hong Kong: Ivory's Fort Knox
item.description: Hong Kong is fast becoming the Fort Knox of ivory.

item.title: Global warming increases pollen
item.description: With global warming, temperature extremes are becoming a norm -- and that's bad news for allergy sufferers.

item.title: World rejects polar bear plan
item.description: A U.S. plan to give new protection to polar bears was voted down Thursday at an international conference on endangered species.

item.title: Study warns global warming 'epic'
item.description: Global warming has propelled Earth's climate from one of its coldest decades since the last ice age to one of its hottest -- in just one century.

item.title: Philippines taps into geothermal
item.description: Eco Solutions looks at how the Philippines is tapping into its geothermal potential.

item.title: Macau's motorcycles go electric
item.description: A Macau company's love for motorcycles is helping the planet at the same time. CNN's Andrew Stevens reports.

item.title: Environmentalists fill U.S. National Mall
item.description: Marching, dancing and poster-waving environmentalists chanting "Hey, Obama. We don't want no climate drama," packed several blocks on and around Washington's National Mall on Sunday, hoping to spur President Barack Obama to take strong measures against climate change.

item.title: China's workforce at a crossroads
item.description: China's extraordinary climb to the world's second largest economy was built on the back of Chinese workers, many of whom left rural farms to migrate for work in coastal factories.

item.title: Chinese bowl sells for $2.2 million
item.description: A rare Chinese bowl bought for about $3 from a yard sale in the U.S. sold for $2.2 million at an auction in New York on Tuesday.

item.title: Pollution 'an economic concern'
item.description: CNN's Philippe Cousteau speaks about Chinese pollution and what can be done to clean up the environmental problems.

item.title: Hollywood dream lost in translation
item.description: When China's most successful homegrown movie went on international release last month, hopes were high that the slapstick comedy, which has drawn comparisons with "The Hangover," would blaze a trail for Chinese-language cinema.

item.title: Xi: China's new boss in a hurry
item.description: Xi Jinping has taken the center stage as China's undisputed paramount leader.

item.title: Li Keqiang named Chinese premier
item.description: Li Keqiang on Friday was named China's premier, the No. 2 position in the Chinese government, completing the once-a-decade transition of leadership in the world's most populous nation.

item.title: Chinese farm claims dead pigs
item.description: A Chinese farm admitted to dumping dead pigs into Huangpu River, which had about 6,000 bloated carcasses pulled from its water this week, state media reported.

item.title: Will China finally 'bite' North Korea?
item.description: North Korea, China's longtime ally, has vexed Beijing for years with its rocket launches, nuclear tests, kidnapping of Chinese fishermen and other erratic behavior. Yet, Beijing has run interference at the United Nations to temper punishments against Pyongyang, and has even helped Pyongyang circumvent sanctions.

item.title: Coca-Cola probed over mapping
item.description: The government of a remote province in western China says it is investigating Coca-Cola over allegations that it illegally mapped parts of the province, as China and the US engage in an escalating war of words over cyber espionage.

item.title: Inflation warning from central bank
item.description: China must be "on high alert" against inflation, central bank governor Zhou Xiaochuan said on Wednesday, striking a hawkish tone at his most important news conference of the year.
